Elephant’s welfare takes precedence over religious tradition, rules Bombay high court.

I'm so angry I don't even know where to start. You know what happened last week? They took Mahadevi. A 40-year-old elephant who lived her entire life in Nandani village in Maharashtra. FORTY YEARS with the same community. The villagers loved her, she was part of their lives, their traditions, their family.

And at 12:30 AM on July 28th, under heavy police protection, they dragged her away. The entire village was crying. Crying! Can you imagine losing a family member like that?

Where did she go? To Mukesh Ambani's son's private zoo in Gujarat. They call it "Vantara" - some fancy Sanskrit name that means "protector of animals." What a joke.

This isn't the first time. I've been following this and the pattern is so obvious it makes me sick:

Remember Pratima from Tripura? Same story. PETA filed a complaint, Supreme Court committee said she needed "rescue," off she went to Vantara.

Then Malti from Rajasthan's Amer Fort. Same exact thing. PETA complaint, court order, straight to Ambani's collection.

Now Mahadevi. Same playbook, same result.

Do you see what's happening here? PETA keeps finding animals in traditional settings - temples, villages, communities where they've lived for decades - and suddenly they're "suffering" and need to be "rescued" by a billionaire's private zoo.

And every single time, the "rescue" destination is the same place. What are the odds?

I did some digging and this is what I found:

Vantara now has over 150,000 animals from 2000+ species. They've moved more than 100 elephants just from Northeast India alone. They've imported 39,000 animals from 32 different countries. This isn't a rescue center - it's the world's largest private animal collection.

The Ambanis have spent over 2000 crores on this project. TWO THOUSAND CRORES. And they're calling it charity, getting tax benefits, government awards, the works.

But here's what really pisses me off - they're planning to open it for tourism. "Sustainable eco-tourism" they call it. You know what that means? They used "rescue" operations to build a massive zoo, got tax breaks doing it, and now they'll charge people to see all the animals they collected.

It's brilliant, actually. Evil, but brilliant.

And the media? Don't even get me started. Multiple news outlets have deleted their critical articles about Vantara. The Telegraph, Deccan Herald, Financial Express - all removed negative stories or replaced them with promotional content. Some journalists even reported getting threatening emails and offers of money to delete their coverage.

When you have Reliance money, you can control the narrative, can't you?

The worst part is how they're destroying communities. These aren't just animals - they're part of people's lives, culture, traditions. Nandani village had a 1200-year-old tradition with elephants. The Northeast communities have been living with these elephants for generations.

But apparently, a billionaire's son in Gujarat knows better than entire communities about animal care.

And the courts? The Supreme Court committee just rubber-stamps every transfer to Vantara. No questions asked. "Animal welfare" they say, as they move elephants from their natural habitat in Northeast to the desert of Gujarat.

This is how power works in India. You have enough money, you can:

* Get court orders in your favor
* Control media coverage
* Silence critics
* Turn theft into "rescue"
* Build a private empire and call it charity

I'm not saying animals shouldn't be helped when they're actually suffering. But this systematic targeting of community animals, this pattern of always ending up at the same billionaire's facility, this media suppression - it's not animal welfare. It's animal collection.

They're using our emotions about animal suffering to build a business empire. They're separating animals from communities that have cared for them for decades, even centuries. They're calling it conservation while destroying the actual human-animal relationships that have existed for generations.

And we're supposed to applaud because a rich family is "saving" animals?

Mahadevi didn't need saving from Nandani village. Pratima didn't need saving from her community. These animals needed support IN THEIR HOMES, not displacement to a private zoo thousands of kilometers away.

But supporting community animal care doesn't build tourism empires, does it?

I don't know what we can do against this kind of money and power. The legal system seems bought, the media is controlled, and they have government support. But at least we can talk about it. At least we can call it what it is.

This isn't animal rescue. This is systematic exploitation disguised as charity.

Elden Ring, the Ardhanarisvara, and Hindu mythology There are thematic links between Elden Ring and Hindu mythology, some of which I believe have previously been overlooked by the lore community.

Notes:

- While I am Indian and I was raised Hindu, most of this is deeper theology than the lay worshipper is generally exposed to. Please don’t mind me quoting Wikipedia at length.
- I am not trying to say that there is a 1:1 relationship between Hindu deities and the deities of the Lands Between.
- Some connections I mention might be tangential or nonexistent.
- When trying to explain the meaning of words, I will be referring to the [Indo-European vocabulary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-European_vocabulary) Wikipedia article and mentioning Latin cognates.

### The Ardhanarishvara

The [Ardhanarishvara](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ardhanarishvara) (Half-Female Lord) in Hindu religious iconography is the half-male, half-female representation of the union of the god Shiva, god of destruction, with his consort Parvati, goddess of motherhood.

> Ardhanarishvara symbolizes that the male and female principles are inseparable. The composite form conveys the [unity of opposites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unity_of_opposites) (*coniunctio oppositorum*) in the universe. The male half of Ardhanarishvara stands for [Purusha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purusha) and female half is [Prakriti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prakriti). Purusha is the male principle and passive force of the universe, while Prakriti is the female active force; both are "constantly drawn to embrace and fuse with each other, though... separated by the intervening axis". The union of Purusha (Shiva) and Prikriti (Shiva's energy, Shakti) generates the universe, an idea also manifested in the union of the [Linga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linga) of Shiva and [Yoni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoni) of Devi creating the cosmos. The Mahabharata lauds this form as the source of creation. Ardhanarishvara also suggests the element of [Kama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kama) or Lust, which leads to creation.
>
> Ardhanarishvara signifies "totality that lies beyond duality", "bi-unity of male and female in God" and "the bisexuality and therefore the non-duality" of the Supreme Being. It conveys that God is both Shiva and Parvati, "both male and female, both father and mother, both aloof and active, both fearsome and gentle, both destructive and constructive" and unifies all other dichotomies of the universe. While Shiva's rosary in the Ardhanarishvara iconography associates him with asceticism and spirituality, Parvati's mirror associates her to the material illusory world. Ardhanarishvara reconciles and harmonizes the two conflicting ways of life: the spiritual way of the ascetic as represented by Shiva, and the materialistic way of the householder as symbolized by Parvati, who invites the ascetic Shiva into marriage and the wider circle of worldly affairs. The interdependence of Shiva on his power (*Shakti*) as embodied in Parvati is also manifested in this form.

The parallel between Radagon/Marika and Shiva/Parvati can be drawn here - the union of two supreme deities into a dual being.

Radagon the symbol of Regression is parallel with Shiva, who embodies Purusha, the unchanging, cosmic consciousness. Marika the symbol of Causality is parallel with Parvati, who embodies Prakriti, the essence of matter and energy, the nature of reality.

The [Samkhya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samkhya) school of Hindu philosophy views reality of being composed of the union of Purusha and Prakriti.

> In Sāṃkhya puruṣa signifies the observer, the 'witness'. Prakṛti includes all the cognitive, moral, psychological, emotional, sensorial and physical aspects of reality. It is often mistranslated as 'matter' or 'nature' – in non-Sāṃkhyan usage it does mean 'essential nature' – but that distracts from the heavy Sāṃkhyan stress on prakṛti's cognitive, mental, psychological and sensorial activities.

See also: [Dualism in Indian philosophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dualism_%28Indian_philosophy%29)

### [Shiva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shiva)

> Shiva is known as *The Destroyer* within the [Trimurti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trimurti), the [Hindu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism) trinity which also includes [Brahma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brahma) (the Creator) and [Vishnu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vishnu) (the Preserver). In the Shaivite tradition, Shiva is the Supreme Lord who creates, protects and transforms the universe.
>
> Shiva has many aspects, benevolent as well as fearsome. In benevolent aspects, he is depicted as an [omniscient](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omniscience) [Yogi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi) who lives an [ascetic life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asceticism#Hinduism) on [Mount Kailash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Kailash) as well as a householder with his wife [Parvati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parvati) and his two children, [Ganesha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ganesha) and [Kartikeya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kartikeya). In his fierce aspects, he is often depicted slaying demons. Shiva is also known as Adiyogi (the first [Yogi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi)), regarded as the patron god of [yoga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoga), [meditation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meditation#Hinduism) and the arts. The iconographical attributes of Shiva are the serpent king [Vasuki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasuki) around his neck, the adorning [crescent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crescent) moon, the [holy river](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_river) [Ganga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ganga) flowing from his matted hair, the [third eye](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_eye) on his forehead (the eye that turns everything in front of it into ashes when opened), the [trishula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trishula) or trident as his weapon, and the [damaru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damaru) (drum).

### [Parvati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parvati), Sati, Durga and Kali

> **Parvati**, **Uma** or **Gauri** is the [Hindu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism) goddess of power, energy, nourishment, harmony, love, beauty, devotion, and motherhood. In her complete form, she is a physical representation of [Mahadevi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahadevi) also known as Adi Shakti, the primordial power behind the creation of the universe, the creator and destroyer. She is one of the central deities of the goddess-oriented sect called [Shaktism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaktism), and the supreme goddess in [Shaivism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaivism). Along with [Lakshmi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakshmi) and [Sarasvati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saraswati), she forms the [Tridevi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tridevi).
>
> Parvati is a powerful, primordial [mother goddess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother_goddess), and also has several fearsome forms and killed evil beings in forms such as Gauri, [Durga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durga), [Kali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kali), the ten [Mahavidyas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahavidyas), and the [Navadurgas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navadurga). Parvati is an embodiment of [Shakti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shakti). In [Shaivism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaivism), she is the recreative energy and power of Shiva, and she is the cause of a bond that connects all beings and a means of their spiritual release. She is also well known as Kamarupa (the embodiment of one's desires) and Kameshvari (the lordess of one's desires).

Parvati is a complex goddess and has many different aspects.

Shiva's first wife was [Sati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sati_(Hindu_goddess)), who immolated herself in a pyre after her father humiliated and insulted her and her husband. A grief-stricken Shiva left the world behind and became an ascetic in the Himalayas. The historical barbaric practice of [Sati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sati_(practice)) involved widows casting themselves into the funeral pyres of their husbands. I think being aware of this atrocity subconsciously made me disturbed by the concept of Kindling Maidens immolating themselves for their lords, though I did not consciously draw the connection until writing this post.

She was reborn as Parvati (lit. mountain woman), and joins Shiva in his ascetic meditations on the peak of Mt. Kailash. Shiva attempts to rebuff her but eventually relents and the two are married once more. They go on to have two children, Ganesha and Kartikeya (more on these below).

When the demon Mahishasura (lit. buffalo-demon) was threatening the gods, Parvati took the form of the fierce [Durga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durga) to slay him. Durga is a warrior aspect, the righteous fury of the gods unleashed against the wicked.

In a later time, the demon Raktabija (lit. blood-seed) attacked and could not be killed because he would respawn duplicates from each drop of blood. As the armies of Raktabija clones swelled, Durga summoned forth the aspect of [Kali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kali), her darkest rage. Kali devoured the demons and drank every last drop of blood to prevent Raktabija from duplicating again. Kali is depicted as blue-skinned, bearing a garland of beheaded demons, her hands stained red with blood, her mouth bearing fangs and a lolling tongue, accompanied by serpents and jackals.

Parvati is the head of a group of mother goddesses called the [Matrikas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrikas). I mention this only because of the similarity in name.

### Blue skin, multiple limbs and Grafting

A common motif in Hindu deific depiction is multiple limbs and/or heads - Durga is depicted as ten-armed, Kartikeya is six-headed, Brahma is three-headed, the demon Ravana is ten-headed, and many more examples. The [Chaturbhuja](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaturbhuja), or four arms (*chatur* means 4, cognate to *quattuor*), is a common way to depict deities.

Many gods - Vishnu and his avatars, Kali, sometimes Shiva, are [depicted as blue-skinned](https://smarthistory.org/understanding-divine-blueness-in-south-asia/) as well.

We see these sorts of depiction with two examples in Elden Ring - the Grafted Lineage and Ranni. Ranni, after burning her original body, is a blue idol with four arms and her [name](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rani) is Sanskrit for queen. Change her clothing and she would not be out of place in a Hindu temple. In particular, she seems similar to popular depictions of Kali.

The sons of Shiva and Parvati are Ganesha and Kartikeya. [Ganesha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ganesha), god of beginnings, wisdom, and obstacles, was [decapitated by Shiva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mythological_anecdotes_of_Ganesha#Decapitation_by_Shiva) and then had the head of an elephant demon grafted on. [Kartikeya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kartikeya), god of war, was born as six boys whom Parvati combined into one. He is often depicted six-headed and riding a peacock. Grafted Scions, with their peacock wing and mutilated combination of bodies, stand out as a twisted reflection of Kartikeya.

### Maya and the Veil of Marika

The concept of [Maya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maya_(religion)) is fundamental to Hindu tradition. Maya means illusion and/or magic, and since the material world is in itself an illusion for immortal souls, there is no difference between illusion and reality.

> Hendrick Vroom explains, "The term *Maya* has been translated as 'illusion,' but then it does not concern normal illusion. Here 'illusion' does not mean that the world is not real and simply a figment of the human imagination. *Maya* means that the world is not as it seems; the world that one experiences is misleading as far as its true nature is concerned." Lynn Foulston states, "The world is both real and unreal because it exists but is 'not what it appears to be'." According to Wendy Doniger, "to say that the universe is an illusion (māyā) is not to say that it is unreal; it is to say, instead, that it is not what it seems to be, that it is something constantly being made. Māyā not only deceives people about the things they think they know; more basically, it limits their knowledge."
>
> Māyā pre-exists and co-exists with [Brahman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brahman) – the Ultimate Principle, Consciousness. Maya is perceived reality, one that does not reveal the hidden principles, the true reality. Maya is unconscious, Atman is conscious. Maya is the literal, Brahman is the figurative *Upādāna* – the principle, the cause. Maya is born, changes, evolves, dies with time, from circumstances, due to invisible principles of nature, state the Upanishads. Atman-Brahman is eternal, unchanging, invisible principle, unaffected absolute and resplendent consciousness. Maya concept in the Upanishads, states Archibald Gough, is "the indifferent aggregate of all the possibilities of emanatory or derived existences, pre-existing with Brahman", just like the possibility of a future tree pre-exists in the seed of the tree.

The power of Marika over illusions, such as drawing a veil over the Shadow lands, could be drawn from the concept of Maya.

### [Brahman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brahman) and the Greater Will

> In Hinduism, ***Brahman*** ([Sanskrit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskrit_language): ब्रह्मन्; [IAST](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Alphabet_of_Sanskrit_Transliteration): *Brahman*) connotes the highest universal principle, the [Ultimate Reality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate_reality) of the [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe). In major schools of [Hindu philosophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_philosophy), it is the non-physical, efficient, formal and final [cause](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_causes) of all that exists. It is the pervasive, infinite, eternal truth, consciousness and bliss which does not change, yet is the cause of all changes. *Brahman* as a [metaphysical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaphysics) concept refers to the single binding unity behind diversity in all that exists.

> [Paul Deussen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Deussen) states that the concept of *Brahman* in the Upanishads expands to [metaphysical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaphysics), [ontological](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontology) and [soteriological](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soteriology) themes, such as it being the "primordial reality that creates, maintains and withdraws within it the universe", the "principle of the world", the "[absolute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_(philosophy))", the "general, universal", the "cosmic principle", the "ultimate that is the cause of everything including all gods", the "divine being, Lord, distinct God, or God within oneself", the "knowledge", the "Self, sense of self of each human being that is fearless, luminuous, exalted and blissful", the "essence of liberation, of spiritual freedom", the "universe within each living being and the universe outside", the "essence and everything innate in all that exists inside, outside and everywhere".

> > This whole universe is *Brahman*. In tranquility, let one worship It, as *Tajjalan* (that from which he came forth, as that into which he will be dissolved, as that in which he breathes).
> >
> > — Chandogya Upanishad 3.14.1
>
> > Man is a creature of his *Kratumaya* (क्रतुमयः, will, purpose). Let him therefore have for himself this will, this purpose: The intelligent, whose body is imbued with life-principle, whose form is light, whose thoughts are driven by truth, whose self is like space (invisible but ever present), from whom all works, all desires, all sensory feelings encompassing this whole world, the silent, the unconcerned, this is me, my Self, my Soul within my heart.
> >
> > — Chandogya Upanishad 3.14.1 – 3.14.3
>
> > This is my Soul in the innermost heart, greater than the earth, greater than the aerial space, greater than these worlds. This Soul, this Self of mine is that Brahman.
> >
> > — Chandogya Upanishad 3.14.3 – 3.14.4

The Greater Will, depicted as being supreme over the gods and demigods, is analogous to Brahman in this comparison.

All are one in the Brahman, and it is being separated from the will that is the ultimate cause of the material world and suffering. The ultimate goal of reincarnation is to become one with Brahman again. This brings to mind the Frenzied Flame and its goal of eradication of all division and individuality.

What am I and how do I embrace my relationship with God Sensitive subject matter warning: Childhood sexual abuse, attempt on my own life, religious abuse, eating disorder, and an overall lack of ubderstanding if I am disrespecting a religion that I so love.

This post will be a recounting of all the struggles that I am having in my life, some related to my relationship with Hinduism, and an appeal for help and guidance on what to do. 

I would like to preface further that I am currently seeing a therapist, am setting up a psychatrist, and will be starting Intensive Out Patient care (IOP) for my mental health this week. This post will also serve as way to hopefully progress my healing process 

I don't know what I am or even who I am really anymore. I can say that I am survivor of childhood sexual, emotional, psychological, and physical abuse; but, those are not what define me and my story. I want to say I am a man but I hold conflicting beliefs on what that even means, I just know that I don't like being one because it means I am like my father in some way (my primary abuser). But then again, I have many postive male role models in my life that are the exact opposite  and who I wish to be like. I could say I am hindu; however, I do not even truly know what it means to be one.

The day after I attempted to take my own life, I saw a dark skinned woman with necklace of skulls and multiple arms holding weapons, heads, and bloody objects while I was meditating on the formerly repressed memories of my sexual abuse. I was in the body of my 10 year old self and was still crying and in terror because of my father and had not even noticed he and the woman with him were gone and I wasn't in the chair that forced to stay in while it was happening. I didn't notice that I was on the bank of a river, before this dark woman, until I was seeing through her eyes at my 10 year old self. Then I was before her, and all i could feel was a sense of calm and relife that my pain was over and I immediately walked up to her in tears and embraced her as if she were my mother. I felt truly safe in her embrace, like I was in the arms of my mother when I was a baby. I cried and cried and cried while she petted my head. Then I abruptly fell out of meditative focus and was silently crying without noticing. 

I did not know it at the time; but, the figure that I saw in meditation was Mahadevi Maa Kali. The Goddess of Death and Time (among many other things). It was this experiance that I cite as the true start of my journey with Sanata Dharma / Hinduism. Before, almost 5 years to the day, I had sudden burst of emotions and feeling of overwhelming lightness and fullness when I attended a school field trip to a Hindu temple primarily dedicated to the great preserver Vishnu. I ignored those feelings until I saw Maa Kali. 

So I began researching Hinduism extensively. I learned how to properly tie knots for the first time in my life after 23 years of struggling with not being able to in order to make Malas. I used the Amethyst beads I had been carrying with me during my attempt and when I was mediating when I saw Kali (I was lookimg into crystal healing and western style meditation at the time), and took them to location of my abuse and turned them into a Mala. I began chanting mantras to Ganesh after I saw a large white elephant's head with its brain exposed in my dreams. But somwhere along the line I stopped. I learned that I could be harming myself if I spoke mantras incorrectly, at the wrong time, and if I ever spoke the wrong ones. I became terrifed of insulting God in all of its forms, the God that I had come to and still do love with all of my heart. The God that I believe to be in all of us, in all life. The God that loves all and that taught me to have love in my heart, even for my abusers, because everyone has a piece of the God that I love in themselves. I can't even get through a 108 round of Om without bursting into tears. 

The past few months I have been at a loss for how to progress my connection to god. I have tried and failed to attend service at the temple I previously mentioned, I felt like I did not fit in or deserve to be in such a holy place.  I have even explored the Chakras and astrology on their surface level. Yet I have not been able to connect with any form of God to the same depth as meditating silently while thinking of Maa Kali, Lord Shiva, or Lord Ganapati holding me like a child. The only thing that has gotten me even close to feeling that connection was contenplating on what Hindu name I might one day adopt. At least it was postive until I remebered the genuine fear of possibly insulting God by not doing it correctly.

So here I am. Where here is and whoever is me. I have no idea what to do to progress on my Hinduism journey. I am taking a class on the religions of Inda this upcoming semester, and so far reading the text book has not helped me much. What do I do? Where do I go from here? I want to feel close to God again instead of stewing in my suffering by binge eating every night and lamenting that my Grandmother pushed me out of christanity as young child with her constant persecution of my dead uncle on the grounds of him being gay. 

Tldr;
I am a damaged individual who is seeking help with connecting to God in all of its forms through Hinduism. Please help. 

Namaste if you have read this far.

The intelligent queen sembian mahadevi was adviced by the super intelligent prime minister Anirudha bharahmarayar to swap the babies but it makes no sense as it is the same Anirudhar who lied to Sundara Chola about Mandakini as he didn't want an unknown woman as the queen, as he feels the child may not be king worthy. So I refuse to accept he would be fine with a random child being made a prince and a possible future king.

Kalki may have introduced the twist to remove blemishes on Uttama Chola, as he had showed Madurantakan as a coward earlier(he came in a palanquin), he didn't want people to think Uttama Chola was a coward, so he introduced the Senthan Amuthan character arc, but Mani dealt it better, Madurantakan in film was braver and more intelligent than the book Maduranthakan, so he maybe a good king kinda thing.

The movie itself was phenomenal, the BGM, cinematography and performances are oscar worthy. The soodanathu ratham reprise was a surprise and I can't wait to hear it again.

Mani has really done the best possible condensing the 5 part novel into epic 2 part movie. I too felt he could have avoided war scenes and focused more on drama, since he is so good at drama and not so good at war scenes.

Aditha Karikalan - Nandini meeting scene is one of the greatest scene in history of cinema!!  
The writing, cinematography( dark lighting with the faces illuminated by lightning flashes was brilliant), music, performances were at their best. Ilayoor Soodar is a purananooru text lamenting about the death of a warrior, no idea why it was played for Mandakini death, either way it worked really well.

They represents the Trimurti and can have different meanings. I will focus on these which Oda could have be inspired from.
